etymologies: early 17th century (denoting a tetrachord divided into two tones and a lower semitone, or ancient Greek music based on this): from French diatonique, or via late Latin from Greek diatonikos ‘at intervals of a tone’, from dia ‘through’ + tonos ‘tone’

definitions: (of a scale, interval, etc.) involving only notes proper to the prevailing key without chromatic alteration.
shortDefinitions: (of scale, interval, etc.) involving only notes proper to prevailing key without chromatic alteration

definitions: (of a melody or harmony) constructed from a diatonic scale.
shortDefinitions: (of melody or harmony) constructed from diatonic scale
